title: Sir Walter Barttelot, 3rd Baronet
text:
Sir Walter Balfour Barttelot, 3rd Baronet, <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">DSO</a> (22 March 1880 – 23 October 1918) was of the <a href="Barttelot%20baronets">Barttelot Baronetcy</a> and grandson of <a href="Sir%20Walter%20Barttelot%2C%201st%20Baronet">Sir Walter Barttelot, 1st Baronet</a>. The Barttelots resided at "At Ford", in the <a href="parish">parish</a> of <a href="Stopham">Stopham</a> <a href="Sussex">Sussex</a>.
Early life and military career.
Barttelot was born at The Manor, <a href="Sidmouth">Sidmouth</a> on 22 March 1880. He was educated at <a href="Fonthill%20School">Fonthill</a>, <a href="East%20Grinstead">East Grinstead</a> and <a href="Eton%20College">Eton College</a>.
He then attended the <a href="Royal%20Military%20College%2C%20Sandhurst">Royal Military College, Sandhurst</a> and was commissioned as a <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a> in the 2nd Battalion, <a href="Dorsetshire%20Regiment">Dorsetshire Regiment</a> on 6 December 1899. The regiment was stationed in South Africa, so he was involved throughout the <a href="Second%20Boer%20War">Second Boer War</a>, part of the time he was an <a href="Aide%20de%20Camp">Aide de Camp</a> to <a href="General%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">General</a> <a href="Talbot%20Coke">Talbot Coke</a>, and he also served as a <a href="staff%20officer">staff officer</a> to <a href="Colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Colonel</a> Williams, who commanded a <a href="Mounted%20Infantry">Mounted Infantry</a> <a href="Column%20%28formation%29">Column</a>. He succeeded to the title of 3rd Baronet Barttelot, on 23 July 1900, after his father, <a href="Sir%20Walter%20George%20Barttelot%2C%202nd%20Baronet">Sir Walter George Barttelot, 2nd Baronet</a>, was <a href="killed%20in%20action">killed in action</a> during the Boer War. He transferred to the 1st Battalion, <a href="Coldstream%20Guards">Coldstream Guards</a> on 12 February 1901, returning to the United Kingdom with them in October 1902. The 3rd baronet received the <a href="Queen%27s%20South%20Africa%20Medal">Queen's South Africa Medal</a> with six clasps and the <a href="King%27s%20South%20Africa%20Medal">King's South Africa Medal</a> with two. He married Gladys St. Aubyn Angove, daughter of William Collier Angove, on 17 November 1903.
He was promoted to <a href="first%20lieutenant">lieutenant</a> on 9 November 1903, and to <a href="captain%20%28land%29">captain</a> on 18 May 1910. He served in <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a> from 1906 to 1908, and from 27 June 1911 he was <a href="Aide%20de%20camp">Aide de camp</a>, and from 12 August 1913 to 14 October 1914, <a href="Military%20Secretary%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Military Secretary</a> to <a href="Baron%20Denman">Lord Denman</a> the <a href="Governor-General%20of%20Australia">Governor-General</a> of <a href="Australia">Australia</a>.
First World War.
With the outbreak of the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, Barttelot initially served in France with the 4th (Reserve) Battalion Coldstream Guards, from 12 August 1914, where he was wounded at the <a href="First%20Battle%20of%20the%20Aisne">Battle of the Aisne</a> and also awarded the French <a href="Croix%20de%20guerre">Croix de guerre</a>. He was then appointed a <a href="Staff%20Officer">General Staff Officer, Grade III</a> on 11 February 1915 and was concerned with coastal defence around <a href="Isle%20of%20Portland">Portland</a>, and served in the ill-fated <a href="Gallipoli%20campaign">Gallipoli campaign</a> from July 1915, where he was promoted <a href="major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a> on 1 September 1915. He was appointed a <a href="Brigade%20Major">Brigade Major</a> on 11 January 1916, for the <a href="Mesopotamian%20campaign">Mesopotamian campaign</a>. He was appointed to the <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">Distinguished Service Order</a> (DSO) on 22 December 1916, and appointed GSO, Grade II from 11 September 1917. and was <a href="Military%20Attach%C3%A9">Military Attaché</a> to <a href="Tehran">Tehran</a> from 17 March 1918 with temporary promotion to <a href="Lieutenant-Colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">lieutenant-colonel</a> whilst performing those duties. He was awarded a <a href="brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> promotion to lieutenant-colonel for his service in <a href="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a> on 3 June 1918, and was killed, (aged 38) on 23 October 1918 in Tehran, <a href="Iran">Persia</a> and was buried in the Tehran War Cemetery. In addition to his DSO, he had also been <a href="Mentioned%20in%20Despatches">Mentioned in Despatches</a> four times.

Family.
Barttelot was survived by his wife and two sons. The eldest son, <a href="Sir%20Walter%20de%20Stopham%20Barttelot%2C%204th%20Baronet">Sir Walter de Stopham Barttelot, 4th Baronet</a>, was killed in action as a <a href="brigadier">brigadier</a> on 16 August 1944, in <a href="Normandy">Normandy</a> during <a href="Operation%20Overlord">Operation Overlord</a> during the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>. Barttelot was commemorated with memorial services in Stopham Parish Church on 9 November 1918, and at <a href="Holy%20Trinity%20Brompton">Holy Trinity Brompton</a> on 11 November. His widow remarried, to <a href="Commander">Commander</a> N. W. Diggle <a href="Order%20of%20St%20Michael%20and%20St%20George">CMG</a>, <a href="Naval%20Attach%C3%A9">Naval Attaché</a> in Rome, on 30 April 1920.
Barttelot's brother, <a href="Lieutenant-Commander">Lieutenant-Commander</a> Nigel Kenneth Walter Barttelot had been killed in the early days of World War I, whilst commanding the destroyer <a href="HMS%20Liberty%20%281913%29">HMS "Liberty"</a> during the <a href="Battle%20of%20Heligoland%20%281914%29">Battle of Heligoland Bight</a>.
Legacy.
Barttelot Road, in <a href="Horsham">Horsham</a> <a href="West%20Sussex">West Sussex</a>, takes its name from the family.
